texts.text-8-2: We generally associate exercising, eating a balanced diet, and visiting a primary care doctor at least once a year as the main health care practices.
texts.text-8-3: However, there is a vital aspect of our balance that we do not give the importance it deserves, which is mental health.
texts.text-8-4: According to the World Health Organization (WHO) (2004), a state of complete physical, mental, and social well-being goes beyond the absence of ailments or diseases.
texts.text-8-5: For this reason, health care should not be reduced to physical aspects, as it involves a more comprehensive view of well-being.
texts.text-8-6: Based on this more complete and integral vision, a challenge arises that involves being clear that the different areas of health care are not limited to a specific institution, group, or individual. Comprehensive health requires a share of responsibility from all parties.
texts.text-8-7: The concept of self-care consists of all those daily practices and decisions that a person, group, or family develops to take care of their health and have a better quality of life (Correa, 2016).
texts.text-8-8: Therefore, establishing moments of self-care is essential, as it influences overall health and provides multiple benefits such as:
texts.text-8-9: reduce stress, improve mental health, better manage emotions, avoid burnout syndrome (synonymous with professional weariness, its literal translation into Spanish is "being burned out"), etc.
texts.text-8-10: In this manual, we will address the different types of self-care and how they can be put into practice comprehensively to ensure the physical and mental health of people who work directly with populations who are victims of gender-based violence and/or are in vulnerable situations.
texts.text-9-2: It is an approach to health where the individual is responsible for taking individual and/or collective actions that can strengthen or restore the state of overall wellbeing, as well as prevent diseases.
texts.text-9-3: In this sense, self-care requires the development of practices that, according to the interests and learned skills, as well as the usual customs of the culture, promote survival and encourage taking responsibility for solving what affects one's health.
texts.text-9-4: Personal practices that constitute self-care, while varying among individuals, primarily aim at the preservation of health.
texts.text-9-5: Therefore, indeed having a proper diet and doing healthy physical activities are part of possible self-care practices, but it is also important to have good social relationships, learn to recognize and value one's own emotions, rest when necessary, among other personal care activities.
texts.text-10-2: Among the principles of self-care, some of the following elements should be considered when addressing it (Uribe, 1999; Correa, 2016):
texts.text-10-3: It is an act of life that allows people to become active subjects in caring for their health and is a voluntary process of a person towards themselves.
texts.text-10-4: It is an individual responsibility and a daily commitment that is based on a formal and informal health system with social support.
texts.text-10-5: When performing self-care practices, either for protective or preventive purposes, people develop them with the certainty that they will improve their level of health.
texts.text-10-6: For self-care to occur, a certain degree of personal development is required, which is mediated by a permanent strengthening of self-concept, self-control, self-esteem, self-acceptance, and resilience.
texts.text-11-2: Incorporating self-care routines is key to improving quality of life and preventing diseases, both physical and mental (such as anxiety, depression, among others), as well as for recovery in case of experiencing them.
texts.text-11-3: In fact, it has been identified that by incorporating these practices, there is greater adherence to therapeutic treatments by patients with chronic illnesses (Bastidas, 2007).
texts.text-11-4: This favors the restoration of health and empowers the person, giving them more resources and control over the situation that affects their well-being.
texts.text-11-5: Learning to take care of oneself is a way to improve the relationship with oneself, it involves knowing oneself better and understanding which practices and interests contribute to one's own health.
texts.text-11-6: Self-care invites the person to think about what really excites and inspires them, helping to better understand the physical, social, cognitive, and emotional needs that benefit them.
texts.text-11-7: These efforts and care send a message about the value we place on health and self-care, allowing us to visualize the importance of the person, in general terms it can be said to improve self-esteem.
texts.text-11-8: Having greater self-awareness and valuing one's own needs promotes decision-making and the establishment of boundaries both for oneself and towards others.
texts.text-11-9: In essence, it consists of recognizing one's own capabilities and respecting their well-being.
texts.text-11-10: One evidence is the establishment of boundaries that separate work life from personal life. Some people decide not to respond to messages and calls outside of work hours, while others, due to their position or profession, cannot make that decision and opt for other measures. The important thing is to respect their needs.
texts.text-11-11: The incorporation of self-care behaviors enhances productivity: if there is a review of needs and a consequent establishment of limits, the most important ones are prioritized.
texts.text-11-12: The person learns to say no to less important matters and focuses on the goals that help them grow, maintaining a healthy state that allows them to perform optimally.
texts.text-11-13: These decisions have an impact on others, as being focused, a person performs better in areas such as work or family, but primarily the impact occurs on the person who incorporates these behaviors into their life.
texts.text-12-1: In others, the impact is evident not only in the increase in productivity but also in the improvement of interpersonal relationships, as it involves working on aspects such as emotional management and conflict resolution capabilities.
texts.text-12-2: Self-care is not about practicing isolated and meaningless care activities, the goal is to take responsibility for one's own health and, in many cases, start a personal work process, which can take quite a bit of time.

texts.text-13-8: It involves striving to be well for oneself, as you cannot take care of others if you are not well yourself.

texts.text-17-1: Another way to categorize self-care appears when addressing the comprehensive aspect of health.
texts.text-17-2: There is a categorization of care according to the diverse dimensions and needs of human beings, highlighting both physical, emotional, cognitive, social, and even spiritual needs.
texts.text-17-4: Physical self-care: it includes everything related to the well-being of the body, such as having a healthy diet, hygiene habits, and an appropriate sleep regimen, maintaining physical activity, as well as preventing and properly addressing any illness or discomfort.
texts.text-17-5: Emotional self-care: it consists of connecting with one's own emotions and those of others, accepting that they are part of life and that they do not define you.
texts.text-17-6: It is learning that one is not guilty for their own emotions, but one is responsible for the actions that arise from them.
texts.text-17-7: Cognitive self-care: it is essential to exercise our intellectual faculties, be able to stimulate critical thinking, creativity, and other personal competencies.
texts.text-17-8: Learn and develop skills that are of interest to the person.
texts.text-17-9: Social self-care: it involves building healthy bonds and connections, a support network that allows the person to remain healthy.
texts.text-17-10: Take care of relationships, as well as become aware of the impact that certain relationships or social influences may have on oneself.
texts.text-17-11: Spiritual self-care: connecting with one's own values and maintaining a healthy relationship with who one is inside.
texts.text-18-2: One of the most evident ways to take care of oneself is through attention to the body, dedicating sufficient efforts to satisfy the most basic biological needs, developing capacities, and preventing discomfort or complications.
texts.text-18-3: There are many activities that promote body care, and several are of a daily nature.
texts.text-18-4: Self-care is a conscious decision that goes beyond just exercising or eating; it involves reflecting on these needs and taking action to make them healthy.
texts.text-18-5: Physical self-care always has an interrelationship with other aspects such as emotional, social, and cognitive.
texts.text-18-6: Being aware of physical needs will imply taking into account bodily discomfort and addressing any diseases or ailments that the person may be experiencing.
texts.text-18-7: (Bastidas, 2007). And in turn, all those practices that promote disease prevention and health promotion in general.
texts.text-19-1: Among these, the following practices can be mentioned:
texts.text-19-3: Feeding ourselves is one of the main biological needs, it means giving our bodies enough nutrients to subsist and develop.
texts.text-19-4: The truth is that we are rarely aware of the foods we ingest; most of the time it is assumed as just another daily activity, when it is one of the main factors in the appearance of diseases such as diabetes, osteoporosis, anemia, coronary diseases, among others (Socarras, et al.2010 and Savino 2011).
texts.text-19-5: A more active role in nutrition should be taken, and the relationship with food should be questioned.
texts.text-19-6: In other words, it is about having mindful eating, learning to eat based on decisions, considering the body's needs.
texts.text-19-7: It is not about a restrictive diet model, but rather about generating self-awareness and self-control about themselves.
texts.text-20-3: In addition to having an adequate diet, the body needs to exercise to develop muscles and joints, and in general, the acquired energy from nutrients should be expended to maintain balance.
texts.text-20-4: For this reason, part of self-care is based on developing sufficient physical activity according to the body's needs and the stage of development.
texts.text-20-5: This way, healthier lifestyles are promoted, obtaining benefits such as:
texts.text-20-7: by reducing the risk of certain diseases, a better quality of life is generated, both for the present and for the future.
texts.text-20-8: Over time, the deterioration of the body is normal, and physical exercise prevents risks during old age, reduces natural deterioration, as it strengthens the body.
texts.text-20-10: helps to maintain muscle tone during old age.
texts.text-21-2: Physical activity promotes the release of chemicals in the brain that lead to sensations of well-being.
texts.text-21-3: Additionally, there is a sense of accomplishment in reaching a goal or committing to an objective.
texts.text-21-4: In the long term, it can have an impact on self-esteem and help people who are going through mild depression.
texts.text-21-5: There are different ways to practice physical activity, whether through some sporting discipline, yoga, tai chi, or through muscle training routines.
texts.text-21-6: All these activities strengthen the body; the ideal is to find one that involves all these aspects in a balanced manner and is appealing to the person practicing it.
texts.text-21-7: Often, the lack of physical activity or abandoning it is due to a lack of interest, and to obtain benefits, continuity is necessary.
texts.text-22-2: In addition to nourishing and strengthening the body, hygiene should be considered as part of the care, providing the body with attention and cleanliness so that it functions without the risk of diseases.
texts.text-22-3: This is possibly one of the least considered aspects during self-care, given that many of the activities involved, being of a daily nature, do not receive enough attention.
texts.text-22-4: Personal hygiene is key in the prevention of diseases and infections, mainly respiratory and gastrointestinal, as well as in the practice and promotion of healthier habits.
texts.text-22-5: Some of the main hygiene habits that can be mentioned are:
texts.text-22-10: keep the spaces or environments in which you live clean
texts.text-22-11: and take care of the preparation of the food.
texts.text-22-12: These are habits that represent a gesture of self-love, for example, there are those who take a bath as a space for relaxation or care for their hands and feet as a moment of affection for themselves.
texts.text-23-2: Just as it is important to demand and give activity to the body, it is also important for it to rest sufficiently. Both processes are complementary and there cannot be good performance without rest.
texts.text-23-3: The body needs to recover and this process occurs during sleep, as it is the period of least physical demand.
texts.text-23-4: It is a period of rest, not inactivity, as certain processes also important for memory and attention occur at the brain level.
texts.text-23-5: In such a way that it is not only part of physical self-care but also psychological and emotional (Miró, 2002).
texts.text-23-6: Getting enough sleep ensures better cognitive performance the next day and less susceptibility to mood swings.
texts.text-23-7: Some recommendations to ensure a healthy sleep routine are:
texts.text-23-8: Caring for the environment: it is a priority to avoid all those aspects that can interrupt sleep:
texts.text-23-9: It is recommended to sleep in a safe space, on a comfortable mattress, with an adequate pillow, little light, little noise, and a pleasant temperature.
texts.text-23-10: It is also recommended not to use the rest area for other activities like working, playing on consoles or cell phones, eating, etc.
texts.text-23-11: Being consistent: having designated times for going to sleep and waking up allows the body to get used to a schedule and helps it prepare in advance to fall asleep.
texts.text-23-12: Sometimes it's helpful to have a ritual like: drinking a hot tea, taking a bath, meditating, among others.
texts.text-23-13: Do not consume stimulants after mid-afternoon: drinking coffee after mid-afternoon is common and there are people whom it over-activates, disrupting their sleep cycle.
texts.text-23-14: It is recommended to avoid or limit the consumption of stimulant drinks, loaded with sugars and caffeine, as well as to consider the medications used.
texts.text-24-2: It is advisable to take time to recover during the day; a nap can be beneficial.
texts.text-24-3: If this persists, it can disrupt nighttime sleep.
texts.text-24-4: Short naps of about 20 or 30 minutes are recommended.
texts.text-24-5: Try to go to sleep relaxed:
texts.text-24-6: If you can't fall asleep at the usual time, it is advisable to get up and do an activity that induces sleep, like reading or a relaxation technique.
texts.text-24-7: In this way, the association between being unable to sleep and the sleep space is avoided.
texts.text-24-8: the anxiety generated by feeling insomnia can cause an increase in the level of wakefulness.

texts.text-31-4: In addition to taking care of the body physically and identifying emotions, it is important to know how the information received from the outside is interpreted, as well as the ideas one has about the world and oneself.
texts.text-31-5: Cognitive self-care refers to all those activities, actions, and voluntary decisions aimed at improving the well-being of mental functions and thoughts.
texts.text-32-2: It is important to identify those ideas that one has about the world and about oneself, with the expectation that these ideas can be as realistic and favorable as possible.
texts.text-32-3: On some occasions these thoughts (if not managed in a healthy way) can have an impact on a person's development in their life.
texts.text-32-4: Some actions that can be taken to identify and express these ideas are:
texts.text-32-5: - Writing thoughts: writing promotes expression and the release of related tensions.
texts.text-32-6: - Include positive and/or realistic affirmations in your thoughts: it helps redirect your thoughts and have a more accurate view of reality.
texts.text-32-7: Recognizing recurrent or constant thoughts: this will help you have a better assessment of how you identify yourself and the truthfulness of these thoughts or whether they are biased by other people.
texts.text-32-8: Express your thoughts in a safe space: for example, with a health professional or with trusted people.
texts.text-33-1: Knowing how cognitive work is done
texts.text-33-2: Fuenmayor & Villasmil (2008) propose that in the cognitive process there are different skills that facilitate the mental functioning of people.
texts.text-33-3: The main ones are: perception, attention, and memory.
texts.text-33-4: Perception: it is how the information received through the senses is interpreted and understood.
texts.text-33-5: The cerebral and sensory decoding of the information being received is included in order to take actions or store it.
texts.text-33-6: Attention: the person actively captures what they see, hear and focuses on a part of the message.
texts.text-33-7: It also involves how attention is divided among various stimuli or certain types of information are discriminated, facilitating the performance of daily activities over time.
texts.text-33-8: Memory: it is the faculty by which information is retained and recalled.
texts.text-33-9: It is the ability that facilitates storing the knowledge that one has and recognizes in the present about the interpretations that are made of it.
texts.text-34-1: The following are some activities and tools that can be used to maintain and enhance cognitive skills:
texts.text-34-2: Experience different sensations (visual, auditory, and tactile):
texts.text-34-3: through everyday situations such as going to the cinema, listening to music or an audiobook, identifying textures of places and belongings.
texts.text-34-4: Encourage yourself to experience new sensations and identify what is perceived in them.
texts.text-34-6: Books, magazines, materials, and information of interest help maintain the functioning of cognitive skills, and in turn, the person receives attractive information that produces favorable emotions and moments of personal enjoyment.
texts.text-34-8: it promotes the growth of brain areas related to language and increases memory and attention.

texts.text-34-14: Meditation can enhance concentration and focus of attention, as well as a deeper connection with bodily sensations and thoughts.
texts.text-34-16: Just as it is important to stimulate cognitive functions, spaces of silence and relaxation help to avoid the saturation of ideas and information that the brain receives from the environment.
texts.text-34-18: All people are exposed to information they receive from different sources such as friends, family, the environment, and social networks.
texts.text-34-19: But what happens when this information is excessive?
texts.text-34-20: Mental health is affected, causing stress, anxiety, and changes in our mood such as fear and anger due to scenarios we can create from the information we receive.
texts.text-34-21: It is important to discern the information that is received in a healthy way.
texts.text-35-1: - Verify if the information received comes from a reliable source: an institution, an expert on the subject, or a specific person.
texts.text-35-2: This will prevent rumors from affecting the reality of the situation.
texts.text-35-3: - Dedicate a space during the day, free of people, materials or tools that may overload with information: a computer, a cell phone, social networks, news, television, among others.
texts.text-35-4: Express assertively the desire to change the topic or to not receive information when feeling overwhelmed.
texts.text-35-5: A new topic for conversation can be set up where you feel comfortable.
texts.text-35-6: Engage in leisure activities that allow focusing attention on pleasant experiences.
texts.text-35-7: To conclude, not all the information received from the media is useful, and it is important to protect mental health by selecting the messages to be read.
texts.text-36-2: In addition to doing activities that help maintain cognitive health, it is important to know oneself and identify signs that reflect mental exhaustion.
texts.text-36-3: Low performance in daily activities (work, school, sports, etc.).
texts.text-36-6: Problems with family or significant others.
texts.text-36-7: Deliberate behaviors and expressions (anger or crying without apparent reason).
texts.text-37-2: If cognitive exhaustion is identified or you are dealing with a crisis, it is important to take care of yourself by considering the following (Alarcón, 2020):
texts.text-37-3: Not to demand too much intellectually:

texts.text-39-6: All these actions will promote the development of new experiences and will enable the sharing of likes, skills, and abilities.
texts.text-39-7: All people should feel comfortable in these activities.
texts.text-40-2: Talking with other people, in addition to establishing bonds, facilitates the understanding of emotions and the expression of problems or needs.
texts.text-40-3: Some interactions can be sources of support to cope with situations that are sometimes difficult to face on a personal level.
texts.text-40-4: In the same way, it is valid to express and share joys and triumphs with others.
texts.text-40-6: Listening to others facilitates the development of empathy by understanding the realities of each individual.
texts.text-40-7: The person who listens can become a source of emotional, instrumental, and economic support depending on the needs of the people.
texts.text-40-8: It allows recognizing that there are others who may be going through similar stories.
texts.text-40-9: Managing social media in a healthy way:
texts.text-40-10: identify which people you want to be part of your social networks, select those who respect your opinions and do not make judgments or violate your right to privacy.
texts.text-40-11: You have the right to restrict your content with the people you choose.
texts.text-41-2: In any relationship that develops with other people such as friends, family, partner, coworkers, or schoolmates, attention must be paid to the richness of the relationship.
texts.text-41-3: Healthy relationships are free from physical, emotional, and sexual violence and are built on values such as respect.
texts.text-41-4: Knowing the aspects that characterize healthy relationships helps to select those that are beneficial for life.
texts.text-41-5: Some indicators of a healthy relationship are (Bear river head start, 2013):
texts.text-42-1: the understanding of the other person's limits as the value given to them.
texts.text-42-3: It is important to communicate each person's ideas, thoughts, and feelings sincerely and openly; there should be no fear of receiving judgments or disrespectful treatment.
texts.text-42-5: Couples can learn to solve problems and identify new solutions by breaking a problem into smaller parts or discussing the situation.
texts.text-42-7: There can be disagreements and differences in the relationship, however, that does not mean there should be any form of violence or insults. It is important to take some time off if it is identified that the conversation could lead to these actions.
texts.text-42-9: experiences and mutual information are deposited with the security that both people will safeguard it securely.
texts.text-42-11: generates a sense of security and strengthens the bonds in the relationship.
texts.text-42-13: There are different ways of thinking and it is respectable. In decision-making, one must be willing to give and receive, as well as make changes within the relationship for its well-being.
texts.text-42-15: A person's identity should not be based on the relationship; there should be freedom to communicate and go out with friends or engage in personal activities that generate well-being.
texts.text-43-2: Part of taking care of oneself socially involves setting boundaries with other people.
texts.text-43-3: Limits are the rules that each individual sets in relationships with others.
texts.text-43-4: Within those guidelines, a person has the freedom to say 'no' when they want, but at the same time, the person feels comfortable opening up to intimacy and close relationships (Therapist aid, 2016).
texts.text-43-5: There are many types of limits that can be applied in a healthy way, some are:
texts.text-43-6: Physical limits: respect for personal and physical space.
texts.text-43-7: Indicate what is considered appropriate and not in various relationships and moments (hugging, kissing, shaking hands, invading personal spaces).
texts.text-43-8: Intellectual boundaries: there are individual ideas and thoughts, boundaries are applied when respecting the opinions of others and the appropriate moments to discuss or generate a specific conversation.
texts.text-43-9: Emotional boundaries: when a person chooses what type of information to express to others regarding their feelings within a romantic relationship or friendship.
texts.text-43-10: Respecting one's own emotions indicates a healthy establishment of boundaries.
texts.text-43-11: Sexual limits: encompass all aspects of sexuality (emotions, thoughts, and physical contact).
texts.text-43-12: It implies respecting the wishes and ways of expressing sexuality between couples.
texts.text-43-13: Material limits: physical and monetary possessions.
texts.text-43-14: Establishing boundaries indicates recognizing with whom to share or not share these assets, thus strengthening one's own security.
texts.text-43-15: Time limits: the time a person dedicates to the different facets of their life (work, friends, partner, personal time) and the right they have to manage this time based on their needs.
texts.text-43-16: To conclude, if you feel uncomfortable with the approach, behavior, and expressions of other people, it is important to evaluate establishing new boundaries or identifying if it is healthy to maintain or end the relationship. You always have the right to say NO.
texts.text-44-3: Enjoy sharing with your significant others, support the undertaking of new activities in which everyone can feel comfortable.
texts.text-44-4: You can use some of these activities as a reference:
texts.text-44-5: Travel to a new place or country.
texts.text-44-9: Attend significant events of the other
texts.text-44-17: Go out to a restaurant or karaoke
texts.text-45-2: Perhaps one of the least addressed elements of personal care is the topic of spirituality,
texts.text-45-3: it is often overlooked despite its proven relationship with better health and quality of life.
texts.text-45-4: which offers relief to many people, as well as strength and personal growth.
texts.text-45-5: However, religiosity must be distinguished from spirituality,
texts.text-45-6: being the first a series of beliefs, values, and practices linked to an organized institution (Catholic Church, Evangelical, Islamist, Buddhist, etc.).
texts.text-45-7: Instead, spirituality is a more universal aspect,
texts.text-45-8: it is the cultivation of life experience and the search to connect with the divine, the community, life/nature, and oneself (Navas, C and Hyxia, V, 2006).
texts.text-46-1: Although not everyone believes in a religion, anyone can identify with some aspect of spirituality, this search for connection through emotion and personal sense or purpose.
texts.text-46-2: Therefore, despite each religion having its own practices, there are activities that transcend and can be performed by anyone to allow them to better connect with their values and with who they are inside:
texts.text-46-3: Maintain a daily practice of meditation or mindfulness.
texts.text-46-4: Attend a service, either religious or humanistic.
texts.text-46-5: Spend time in nature and reflect on the beauty that surrounds you.
texts.text-46-7: Make affirmations that support your sense of self and your purpose.
texts.text-46-8: Make a trip with the sole purpose of photographing things that inspire you.
texts.text-48-2: Indication: seek a calm and safe place for yourself,
texts.text-48-3: Take a moment to close your eyes and try to think about what you need to take care of yourself.
texts.text-48-4: What are your physical, emotional, social, spiritual, and cognitive needs?
texts.text-48-5: Then, try to express those needs in a letter.
texts.text-48-6: These priorities can change over time and according to your individual and collective conditions.

texts.sectioneli5-0-0: This is a book called 'Manual de Autocuidado'. It means that it is a book about how to take care of ourselves, like when you make sure to be happy and healthy. The image has a person with long hair and is from an organization called Fundasil, which made the book to help people.
texts.sectioneli5-2-0: A 'Self-Care Manual' is like an instruction book that teaches you how to take better care of yourself. Imagine it has tips to keep you healthy and happy, like eating well, getting plenty of rest, and playing with friends. It's like learning to take care of yourself to feel great every day!
texts.sectioneli5-5-0: 'Conte' could be a word to talk about stories or tales. Imagine when someone tells you a story before bed, that's a 'conte'. Many times, 'contes' have characters, adventures, and lessons. It's a fun and magical way to share interesting and important things with others.
texts.sectioneli5-6-0: This is like the index of a book about self-care. It talks about different ways of self-care: physical, emotional, cognitive, social, and spiritual. It also includes exercises and a list of books to learn more. It helps us know on which page to find each topic.
texts.sectioneli5-8-0: When we think about taking care of ourselves, we often only think about exercising or eating well. But it is also very important to take care of our mind, which we call mental health. This greatly helps us to feel good in general. Doing things like resting, talking about what we feel and having fun is part of taking good care of ourselves. This way we are happier and healthier.
texts.sectioneli5-8-1: We usually think that being healthy means exercising, eating well, and visiting the doctor. But there is a very important part that we forget: mental health. This also helps us feel good and balanced.
texts.sectioneli5-8-2: Health is not just about not being sick; it's about feeling good in our body, mind, and with other people. This means that taking care of ourselves is more than just going to the doctor or exercising. We need to consider all parts of our life to be truly well. And we all have a responsibility to help make this happen.
texts.sectioneli5-8-3: Self-care is about doing things every day to take care of yourself and be healthier and happier. It's important because it helps you feel less stressed, manage your emotions better, and avoid feeling very tired. Taking care of yourself a little bit each day is very good for you!
texts.sectioneli5-8-4: This manual talks about how to take care of ourselves in different ways to be healthy and happy. It is very useful for people who help others in difficult situations, so they can also take good care of themselves.
texts.sectioneli5-9-0: Self-care is like taking care of a little plant, which is your body and mind. You are responsible for doing things that help you stay strong and healthy. This includes exercising, eating well, and resting to prevent illnesses. In the image, the person is "watering" their mind and heart, which symbolizes taking care of oneself and staying happy and healthy.
texts.sectioneli5-9-1: Self-care means doing things to take care of ourselves. This includes eating well, exercising, resting when we are tired, and having good friends. It's like taking care of our body and mind so we can be healthy and happy. Each person does it a little differently, according to what they need and like.
texts.sectioneli5-10-0:
Self-care is like taking care of a small garden, but inside you. It's when you take care of yourself to be healthy and happy. To do this, you have to be responsible and think about what is good for you every day. 

Imagine you have a list of things like feeling good about yourself, staying calm, and being strong like a superhero when things are tough. All these things help you improve, and you can do it with the help of your friends and family.
texts.sectioneli5-11-0: Self-care is like taking care of yourself to be healthy and happy. When you do things to feel good, such as choosing what you need and what makes you happy, it can help you not get sick and feel stronger. It also helps you be more productive because you know what is important to you. It is important to say "no" to things that are not as important so you can focus on what matters most to you and helps you grow.
texts.sectioneli5-11-1: Doing things to take care of yourself, like brushing your teeth or playing, helps you feel better and get sick less often. It's also helpful for recovering if you're already sick. When you do this, it's easier to follow the doctor's recommendations and you feel stronger and more confident about what you need to be happy.
texts.sectioneli5-11-2: Learning to take care of yourself is like being your own best friend. It means knowing what things make you feel good and happy, like your favorite hobbies, and understanding what your body and mind need. This helps you feel better about yourself and happier. In short, taking good care of yourself makes you feel important and valuable, like having a superpower of self-esteem.
texts.sectioneli5-11-3: Knowing what we need and setting boundaries helps us make decisions that are good for us. This means understanding what we can do and taking care of our well-being. For example, some people decide not to answer work calls when they are at home. Although not everyone can do this, the important thing is to respect what we need to be well.
texts.sectioneli5-11-4: Taking care of ourselves helps us to be more productive. If we review what we need and set boundaries, we can focus on what is truly important. We learn to say 'no' to things that are not important and focus on what makes us grow. This helps us to be healthier and work better, which is good for both us and the people around us.
texts.sectioneli5-12-0: The text tells us that when we take care of ourselves, not only do we work better, but we also get along better with others. Taking care of oneself is not just doing random senseless activities, but taking responsibility for our health and emotions. The illustration shows a person hugging themselves, suggesting self-love and self-care.
texts.sectioneli5-13-0: Some people think that taking care of oneself is selfish, but it is not true. It is important to take care of yourself to be well and be able to help others. It is also thought that self-care is always the same, but in reality, it can change depending on what you need at different times. It's like adjusting your routine to feel better depending on the day.
texts.sectioneli5-13-1: Some people think that taking care of oneself is selfish, but that is not true. Taking care of oneself means being responsible with your health to be well. If you don’t take care of yourself, you can't help others.
texts.sectioneli5-13-2: Sometimes we do things without thinking much about them, like eating. Self-care means thinking about those things and making better decisions. For example, eating every day doesn't always mean we are eating healthily. It's important to be mindful of what we do and choose what's best for our bodies.
texts.sectioneli5-13-3: Sometimes people think that taking care of oneself always has to be done in the same way every day. But that's not true! In reality, self-care is like a game that adapts. Depending on how you feel or what you need each day, you can change what you do to take care of yourself. It doesn't always have to be the same.
texts.sectioneli5-14-0: Self-care means taking care of ourselves, and there are some misconceptions about this. Sometimes people think that taking care of oneself is always the best for oneself, as if it were something magical, but in reality it is more about doing things that make us feel good, that are good for us. It's not always about spending a lot of money, because there are simple things that also help, like taking time for oneself. Moreover, self-care is not just about resting; it includes things like exercising or learning something new. It is about developing the habit of understanding what we need to be well.
texts.sectioneli5-14-1: Sometimes we think that taking care of ourselves means always doing the best, but in reality, it is more important to look after our health and do what makes us feel good. We should not force ourselves to do things we don't like. What is important is that what we do aligns with what we want and need in life.
texts.sectioneli5-14-2: Sometimes we think that taking care of oneself only means resting, but that's not the case. Taking care of oneself can be exercising, learning new things through play, or simply doing something that makes you feel good. It's not always about sleeping or doing nothing; it's about doing things that help you be healthy and happy.
texts.sectioneli5-14-3: Sometimes it is thought that taking care of oneself requires a lot of money. This is not true, because there are free ways to do so, although you will need to dedicate some time for that.
texts.sectioneli5-14-4: Taking care of oneself means being like a superhero who knows what good things to do to feel well. It's not something you're born knowing; you learn it gradually. It's important to realize the things we need and make them part of our routine, like brushing teeth or eating vegetables, to be healthy and happy.
texts.sectioneli5-15-0: Self-care is when a person does things to take care of themselves. It can be something you do alone, like when you look in the mirror to make sure you are okay and happy. This is important so that you feel good and healthy.
texts.sectioneli5-15-1: Individual self-care is when you make sure to take care of yourself. This means doing things like eating well, getting enough sleep, and brushing your teeth, because you know it's important for feeling good and being healthy. It's like when an adult reminds you to take a break or play, because it's good for you.
texts.sectioneli5-16-0: Collective self-care is when we take care of others in our community, like friends. It's like when we pick up trash together or share a funny book. Although we start by taking care of ourselves, we must also help each other so that everyone is well and happy. For example, you can join a group that plants trees or plays sports. It's like saying "I support you, friend" and helping to make the world a better place.
texts.sectioneli5-17-0: When we take care of ourselves, we not only think about being physically strong and healthy. We must also take care of our feelings, thoughts, relationships with other people, and what we feel inside, like the soul. That way, we can be happy in all parts of our life.
texts.sectioneli5-17-1: Taking care of our body is like taking care of a plant. We need to give it good food, which is like water for the plant. We also have to sleep well, which is when the plant rests. Exercising is like stretching out in the sun to grow strong. And if something ever bothers us or hurts, we should go to the doctor to feel good again.
texts.sectioneli5-17-2: Emotional self-care is like learning to listen and understand how you feel and how others feel. Imagine your emotions are like friends telling you how your day is going. You must know that it's okay to feel sad, happy, or angry. What's important is what you do after feeling that way, because you are responsible for your actions, not your emotions.
texts.sectioneli5-17-3: Cognitive self-care means taking care of our mind. It's like when we play to think in new or creative ways, learning things that interest us. This helps our brain stay strong and allows us to have fun while learning.
texts.sectioneli5-17-4: Social self-care is about making friends and taking care of our relationships to feel good. It is also important to think about how the people around us affect us. Having good friends helps us be happy and healthy.
texts.sectioneli5-17-5: Spiritual self-care is like listening to your heart and thinking about what is important to you. It's having a special and quiet moment where you can reflect and feel good about yourself. This way, you feel happy and at peace inside, much like how you relax after playing.
texts.sectioneli5-18-0: Physical self-care is about taking special care of our body. It is important to eat well, exercise, and rest to feel healthy. It is also good to consider how we feel physically and do things that help us feel better. All of this helps us to not get sick and keeps us happy.
texts.sectioneli5-18-1: Taking care of oneself means doing things that help our body stay healthy. These can be simple things we do every day, like eating well, exercising, and resting. All these things help prevent us from feeling unwell or having health problems.
texts.sectioneli5-18-2: Taking care of oneself is not just exercising or eating well; it's about thinking about what our body needs and doing healthy things. It is also linked to how we feel, relate to others, and think. Everything is connected to keep us healthy.
texts.sectioneli5-18-3: Taking care of yourself means paying attention when your body feels bad or is sick. It's like listening to what your body needs to be healthy and happy, and doing things that help you avoid getting sick in the future.
texts.sectioneli5-19-0: A healthy diet means giving our body the necessary food to be strong and healthy. The image shows someone enjoying their food. It's important to think about what we eat, because that helps prevent diseases and feel better. The idea is to learn to eat mindfully and listen to what our body needs.
texts.sectioneli5-19-1: Eating is very important for our body to grow strong and healthy. We need to choose our foods well to avoid feeling bad or getting sick. Sometimes, we don't pay attention to what we eat, but it's key to staying healthy and preventing diseases like diabetes and heart problems. So, eating well is like giving our body superpowers.
texts.sectioneli5-19-2: We need to think more about what we eat and how food makes us feel. Instead of following strict rules, it’s important to understand what our body needs and make good decisions for ourselves. This way, we befriend food and take better care of our body.
texts.sectioneli5-20-0:
Exercising is very important for keeping our body healthy and strong. Not only eating well, but also moving our body helps us to stay healthy.

When we do physical activity, our muscles and bones strengthen. This is good to feel well now and for when we are older. It helps us prevent illnesses and stay strong for a long time.
